description.narrative:
Blatant disregard for the rule of law, pervasive culture of impunity, and intensified political repression and conservative fundamentalism are constricting democratic spaces across Southeast Asia (SEA), particularly in Philippines and Indonesia. The harsh socio-political landscape breeds more violent and discriminatory spaces for women. For example, Indonesia is still battling with discriminatory national and local bylaws while the Philippines is still suffering from state-sponsored misogynistic violence. All these normalize violence against women and girls, and particularly those women facing marginalization, such as: Lesbians, Bisexual and Transgender (LBTQ) women, women living with disabilities, indigenous women, victims of (sexual) violence and exploitation women. It is time to create a counterculture to the rising authoritarianism, misogyny, and sexism towards combatting the normalization and high incidence of violence and discrimination against women and girls, particularly those from marginalizedcommunities and/or sectors. To stimulate this, Women#s Legal and Human Rights Bureau - WLB (in the Philippines) and Kalyanamitra (in Indonesia) are implementing a project to teach feminism in SEA using a participatory approach.
This project entitled #Feminist School for Women and Young Women Activists in Indonesia and the Philippines: Towards developing Transformative and Sustainable Leadership Among Marginalised Groups of Womenin Southeast Asia# aims to empower a new generation of (marginalised) women/young women to become activists and leaders committed to work for social change, equality, and the protection of women and girls through women#s movement building. Towards this end, feminist leadership modules are developed specifically for Indonesia and Philippines, and later on for SEA in general, taking into consideration the distinct contexts of the two countries as well as their similarities especially for marginalized women. Workshop discussions for the development of modules will involve marginalized women communities, and veteran activists and younger feminists to promote intergenerational learning. The modules will be written in local language so communities and even young women can replicate someof the sessions in the training especially those on women#s human rights and discrimination, protection, and intersectionality. Such modules are put practice through the establishment of feminist schools in the Philippines and Indonesia respectively. Finally, Regional Feminist Camp (with participationof women from Cambodia, Myanmar, Thailand, and Laos) will be organized in the last phase of the project to fortify solidarity among women and ensure sustainability of women#s movement in SEA.
Through these activities, young women activists will be trained to apply critical-thinking and feminist lens on issues relating to gender issues, sexuality, feminist leadership, and human rights, particularly on issues of accessibility of services and resources for marginalized women. These young women are expected to carry their learnings and feminist perspectives in their chosen field of work, to influence others in creating safe spaces for women/young women; thereby, ensuring that women#s issues will not be left behind by the bigger social movements.

participating-org.narrative:
The Womens Legal and Human Rights Bureau Inc. (WLB), formerly Women#s Legal Bureau, was established in 1990 by feminist human rights advocates wanting to effectively address the prejudices suffered by Filipino women before the law and in the legal system. WLB emerged as the first consciously feminist legal organisation pushing for feminist legal advocacy as a strategy for the promotion and defence of women#s human rights. Its mission today is primarily to actively engage in advocacy together with other women#s groups to transform the law and the legal system, and engage its institutions, towards the empowerment of women, especially in the grassroots. This is being pursued in furtherance of the right of women to self-determination and the advancement of their dignity, rights and leadership, in concert with national and global movements for alternative development.
WLB and Kalyanamitra will work hand-in-hand inimplementing this project. These organizations have been active within the women#s movements in their respective countries and in SEA for more than two decades. As such, they have consistently applied feminist perspectives in their advocacy works that include educating women#s grassroots organizations, writing modules, and providing trainings on women#s human rights. These, together with their close linkages with women community organizations, show that WLB and Kalyanamitra are equipped with the technical skills and expertise necessary for the realization of this project goals.
Kalyanamitra was established on the 28 of March of 1985, as the first feminist organization in Jakarta, Indonesia. To achieve its long-term vision to create community and state system with gender equality and justice through strengthening the capability of women with the principle of care and solidarity, Kalyanamitra has four missions : (1) To strengthen the facilitated community to be a social actor in their area through providing and spreading information and knowledge and critical education; (2) To do studies based on community facilitation to be a recommendation for policy change; (3) To improve public awareness about gender injustice issue; (4) To develop public policy advocacy that has gender perspective. Since its establishment, Kalyanamitra as has accumulated a lot of experience for conducting research, capacity building and developing training module on gender, feminism and CEDAW, advocacy and campaign on the issue of Violence Against Women, and community organizing of women's groups.
Both WLB and Kalyanamitra are members of the Weaving Women#s Voices in Southeast Asia (WEAVE) since 2014. WEAV is a feminist regional network of women#s organizations and advocates working at the national level in six countries in Southeast Asia.
WOMENS LEGAL AND HUMAN RIGHTS BUREA
